page.title: 18CONSERVATION IN SANDHURST
page.content: SEVERAL SMALL CONSERVATION AREAS At Bengrove Farm near Sandhurst there are some Decoy Pools (GR 834226) which were originally built by monks as a fish larder. They have been left in an untouched state to form a home for wild life. Badgers, foxes and pheasant are among the inhabitants. On Singleton Farm there are four brick pits near the river (GR 817232). They were once used as withy beds for basket making. One of them is now protected by the Conservation Trust as a bird sanct- uary. Swans and other water fowl are to be found living in these ponds. High Redding Hill on the opposite bank of the river to Sandhurst is a steep- sided ridge where natural meadow grasses and plants are allowed to grow without grazing or ploughing. In each case farmers and conservation- ists cooperate to preserve wildlife.
